item.title: MindsEye’s Cast is a Rainbow That’s Worth the Storm
item.description:
While it’s no secret that Build a Rocket Boy’s new ‘ GTA Clone’, MindsEye, has gotten off to a rough start, the game still has its hidden strengths. So, especially if MindsEye ’s troublesome launch issues get addressed, and the developers’ tentative plans for expanding the IP into a larger universe come to fruition, it might be worth keeping an eye on this game and giving it a second chance in the near future. After all, comeback stories for games after a troubled launch aren’t unheard of nowadays, so a little extra love and support could be just what the doctor ordered for MindsEye .

Regardless of MindsEye ’s future potential, there’s still arguably one great reason why players should consider weathering the storm to experience one of this game’s greatest strengths: the outstanding performances from MindsEye ’s voice artist cast. Ultimately, MindsEye ’s cast of main characters arguably makes this game an experience worth having, despite the game’s controversial flaws.

MindsEye Features a Stacked Voice Cast

The playable character Jacob Diaz in MindsEye is voiced by Alex Hernandez, famously known for their role as Lincoln Clay in Mafia 3 . Jacob Diaz is an ex-special ops soldier who was enhanced with a neural implant that allows him to control a combat drone. When players step into Jacob’s shoes, he’s attempting to reconnect the missing pieces from his past after his implant led to a catastrophic event. In order to do so, Jacob must form alliances with some of the brightest minds of the city of Redrock to discover the origins and true potential of his experimental implant.

Without naming their in-game characters for the sake of potential spoilers, these bright minds of characters among MindsEye ’s cast are stacked full of industry veterans. Alongside Alex Hernandez’s portrayal of Jacob Diaz in MindsEye , the game’s casts bring a unique version of their likeness to their character in MindsEye , enhancing their performance with an extra layer of immersion. MindsEye ’s cast of industry veterans notably includes:

  • Tanya Alexander ( Tomb Raider , Fire Escape: An Interactive VR Series )
  • Elizabeth Arends ( Street Fighter 6 )
  • Anjali Bhimani ( Dune: Awakening , Sunderfolk , Avowed , and more)
  • Giselle Gilbert ( Resident Evil 7 , Afterparty, Fire Escape: An Interactive VR Series )
  • David Haley ( The Amazing Spider-Man 2 , Diablo 3 )
  • Erika Ishii ( Mortal Kombat 1 , Rift of the Necrodancer , Dragon Age: The Veilguard , and more)
  • Iman Nazemzadeh ( Fire Escape: An Interactive VR Series , Call of Duty: Black Ops 2 , Roadkill )
  • Ritesh Rajan ( Thirsty Suitors, Journey to Foundation , Starfield , and more)
  • Isaac Robinson ( Avowed , Mighty Morphin' Power Rangers: Rita's Rewind , Batman: Arkham Shadow , and more
  • David Sakurai ( Assassin’s Creed Shadows )
  • Jake Thomas ( Brave: The Search For Spirit Dancer )
  • Kirk Thornton ( Dune: Awakening , Xenoblade Chronicles X , Sonic X Shadow Generations , and more)
  • Elias Toufexis ( Fortnite , Death Stranding , Starfield , and more)
  • Jay Walker ( Man Eater )
  • Reggie Watkins ( Call of Duty: Black Ops 6 , Call of Duty: Black Ops Cold War , Call of Duty: Mobile , and more)

Among these talented voice artists, David Bateson will allegedly be reprising their role as Agent 47 for an upcoming Hitman collaboration side mission in MindsEye .

MindsEye’s Cast Performances Are Its Saving Grace

Ultimately, each of the main characters’ performances is one of MindsEye’s biggest strengths. Despite its flaws, the strong cast performances are one area where MindsEye arguably lives up to its acclaimed fame of being a ‘ GTA clone.’

For a great many reasons, it’s unfortunate that the launch of MindsEye was troubled by technical issues, especially considering the outstanding performances of the game’s cast will go unseen by many gamers. If nothing else, these performances alone arguably make the game an experience worth having, despite the critiques surrounding the current state of the game. So, regardless of whether MindsEye could get the Cyberpunk 2077 post-launch treatment and overcome the issues it faces at launch, players should still consider weathering the storm to see the rainbow that is the great performances of the game’s cast.

6 Images
6 Images

item.title: Elden Ring Nightreign: Hardest Bosses To Defeat Solo, Ranked
item.description:
Summary

  • Godskin Duo is a challenging gank fight, making it tough for solo players due to having to manage two bosses at once.
  • Gladius, Beast of the Night, presents a tough solo challenge with a three-headed beast that overwhelms players.
  • Heolstor the Nightlord is the toughest boss for solo players, requiring careful planning and quick leveling up to survive.

FromSoftware is known for creating some of the most challenging and grueling boss fights in all of gaming, pushing veteran players to their limits and introducing new players to a different level of difficulty. The bosses are the cornerstone of the soulslike genre, and Elden Ring Nightreign puts them front and center.

With plenty of returning bosses and a few new faces, the list of difficult fights is pretty long, but when it comes to entering a run alone, some of the fights can feel even more punishing. This can be due to battles being balanced around three players or because they demand significant levels of precision. For those brave enough, here are the hardest Elden Ring Nightreign bosses to take on in a solo setting .

8 Godskin Duo

The Same Pain All Over Again

  • Can be encountered as both a night 2 boss and in old Evergaols
  • Same moveset as the base game, with additional second phase attacks for each
  • Drops: One Dormant Power, Runes

The Godskin Duo was always considered to be one of the hardest fights in Elden Ring , so when the pair showed their faces again in Nightreign , it was obvious that the challenge wasn't going to get any easier. The boss can appear in evergaols and also as a night two encounter, providing a sizable task for groups to take on and a monstrous one for solo players.

The reason the fight is so painful is the same as before: It's a gank fight. The individual Godskins are pretty manageable by themselves, but with two on the table at the same time, it can be incredibly hard to find windows to attack, especially for melee characters. There are plenty of other bosses in Limveld that players might have a hard time with, but few have the same level of power as these two.

7 Gladius, Beast Of The Night

He Might Be The First, But He Packs Quite The Punch

  • Tricephalos Expedition
  • Long-range swings and fast gap closes
  • Immune to madness, strong against fire, weak against sleep and holy
  • Drops: Old Pocketwatch, Night of the Beast, Relics

Gladius is the first of the Nightlords that players will face at the end of night three, but that doesn't mean he's a walk in the park. Boasting speed, aggression, range, and damage all in one, it doesn't matter how prepared the player is or how many fights they have won; the three-headed beast can always come out on top. When taking him on solo, the problems only get worse.

The biggest challenge comes from the second phase, where the Lord splits into three segments that each act independently and are hungry for the player's blood. It's a game of juggling with three players, but with every head focusing on a single target, solo players will have to run and pray that they don't get surrounded and taken out in one fell swoop.

6 Nameless King

Just As Brutal As Ever

  • Two-phased mounted fight
  • High lightning damage
  • Drops: One Dormant Power, Runes

The king is back and badder than ever. The Nameless King is one of the most iconic Souls bosses of all time and is also among the hardest. The two-phased encounter brings with it a huge health pool, high-speed attacks, and a lot of unexpected moves that seemingly come out of nowhere.

What makes the fight particularly hard in solo is the lack of windows there are to heal or even get a hit in. With an arena much smaller than in the original fight, players have very little room to maneuver around him and will find themselves being pushed up against the rain with no one to take the aggro away. If he ever shows up on that second night, then the player is going to be in for a tough time; unlike other challenging fights in the castles or evergaols, it's a fight they have to win in order to beat the run.

5 Adel, Baron Of The Night

No Margin For Error

  • Gaping Jaw Expedition
  • Large area attacks and a huge grab hitbox
  • Immune to madness, strong against fire, weak to poison, scarlet rot, frost, and sleep
  • Drops: Night of the Baron, Relics

Adel is the second lord on the expedition list and is for sure one of the tougher ones, bringing with it some incredibly misleading hitboxes and a grab attack that just never seems to miss. The boss has plenty of tricks up its scaly sleeves, like poisonous pools and gigantic AoE attacks that require a good set of legs in order to run away in time.

Solo players will have a tough time taking any meaningful chunks off its health bar, as not only is the boss extremely tanky, but it is also very hard to hit in between its attacks. On top of this, the grab attack does extreme bleed damage all at once, which is normally enough to one-shot squishy characters. With no one to cancel it or revive the player, one single bite can mean the end of a good run.

4 Libra, Creature Of Night

Enough To Drive Anyone Mad

  • Equilibrious Beast Expedition
  • Madness build-up from attacks and certain moves
  • Immune to sleep, strong against magic, weak to madness
  • Drops: Night of the Demon, Relics

Libra is a peculiar fight that brings plenty of madness with it, both literally and figuratively. Many of its attacks inflict madness build-up, one of which can only be prevented by picking up small objects on the ground. Despite also having a weakness like all the other Lords, said weakness is Madness, which is not an easy effect to come by.

The biggest problem for a solo player here comes from a specific attack that spawns a bunch of sigils all around while Libra itself is immune to damage. If they are not all destroyed in time, a huge explosion happens that can easily wipe out even healthy targets. Some of them are easily hittable, but the rest float high above the player's head, meaning that if they don't have a ranged weapon, they might as well say goodbye to the victory screen.

3 Mountaintop Ice Dragon

Time Is The Biggest Enemy

  • Mountaintop Shifting Earth event
  • AoE frostbite build-up
  • Drops: Legendary Armament, Runes

The Mountaintop is a ruthless shifting earth event that brings with it a difficult-to-traverse area full of ice and angry dragons. The main boss in the area is the Mountaintop Ice Dragon, which shakes the earth and induces frostbite build-up to anyone who dares to step even a foot into the mist.

The fight is particularly challenging in solo play. Firstly, its health bar is pretty huge and requires a decent weapon and character level to take down. Secondly, even with the buffs scattered through the mountains, the frostbite can still chunk the player repeatedly, forcing them to retreat and heal in an area where there is little time to escape from the storm.

2 Naturalborn Of The Void

Cutting It Down To The Wire

  • Noklateo Shifting Earth event
  • Area magic attacks with a weak point on its head
  • Strong against fire, magic, light, and holy
  • Drops: One Dormant Power, Runes, guards Favor of Noklateo (one-time resurrection)

Naturalborn of the Void is another returning fight that sees players taking on a familiar foe. This time, however, the stakes are much higher. Normally, players can be ready to take on the city after an initial day of fighting, but due to the size of the city and the other potential rewards that lie inside, it can be hard to clean up everything by the time the final zone shows itself.

When facing the boss alone, the toughest part is time, as the arena is always located right on the edge of the map, meaning that if the player isn't quick enough or can't deal enough damage, then it's either a complete waste of time or death knocking at the door. The reward itself is incredibly powerful if players can manage to take the boss down, but it comes down to whether the risk is worth it or not.

1 Heolstor The Nightlord

The Toughest Challenge There Is

  • Night Aspect Expedition
  • First health bar fake-out into aggressive melee and ranged AoE
  • Immune to poison, frostbite, madness, and bleed
  • Weak to holy
  • Drops: Night of the Lord, Primordial Nightlord's Rune, Relics

Heolstor is the final Nightlord on the expedition list, and he lives up to his name and then some. A brutal fight that comes with ridiculous area attacks and chains that have absurd reach, players need to be on their A-game to take on the challenge and make it through unscathed.

The toughest part about the fight is the level of aggression that Heolstor has. He can jump extremely far, and with no one to take the aggro, all that damage will be coming straight for the single player. Also, when playing alone, players need to have a really good plan and idea of how to level up as quickly as possible, as going into a fight like Heolstor underleveled is basically asking for a loss. He requires incredible attention in the build-up and even more during it, testing players' reflexes and stamina in a fight that rivals some of the best in the series.

8 Images
8 Images

item.title: Wuthering Waves: Septimont Sonance Casket Locations
item.description:
Upon discovering Septimont and activating all beacons, players can start collecting sonance caskets to obtain valuable rewards in Wuthering Waves . Although the process is time-consuming, it's not difficult at all as most caskets are found in plain sight.

Septimont Sonance Casket Location In Wuthering Waves

There are a total of 55 sonance caskets scattered all over Septimont in Wuthering Waves .

Titanborne Expanse Sonance Casket Location In Wuthering Waves

Sonance Casket Location #1

From the Titanborne Expanse's northwest resonance beacon, fly northwest to a small island to find a sonance casket.

Sonance Casket Location #2

Fly southeast to see another one under a bridge.

Sonance Casket Location #3

Head east to find a third sonance casket under a rock arch.

Sonance Casket Location #4

Proceed east and grab the next sonance casket.

Sonance Casket Location #5

Turn north and climb the building to grab another casket.

Sonance Casket Location #6

Fast-travel to the same beacon and climb the nearby mountain to see a sonance casket at the top.

Sonance Casket Location #7

Teleport to the resonance nexus to see a sonance casket on top of a round building.

Sonance Casket Location #8

Go west and fly down to find a destroyed ruin. Head to the lowest floor and go inside the side room to find the casket.

Sonance Casket Location #9

Fly northwest and grab the sonance casket from the top of a small mountain. You can reach this casket from the 6th casket location as well.

Sonance Casket Location #10

Go southeast of the resonance nexus and fly under the bridge to see the sonance casket.

Sonance Casket Location #11

Continue northeast and glide down to grab the casket.

Sonance Casket Location #12

Travel east and fly high to get the next sonance casket.

Sonance Casket Location #13

Proceed north to find a casket on top of a column.

Sonance Casket Location #14

From the southeastern resonance beacon, run north and jump down to find a sonance casket on a wooden platform.

Sonance Casket Location #15

Proceed north and go under a destroyed platform to find a casket.

Sonance Casket Location #16

Go around the mountain to the east and go up to find the sonance casket on top of a tree.

Sonance Casket Location #17

Teleport to the Border Mountains' top resonance beacon and head east to climb a mountain and find a casket under an arch.

Border Mountains Sonance Casket Location In Wuthering Waves

Sonance Casket Location #18

Go back to the same resonance beacon and grab the sonance casket located north.

Sonance Casket Location #19

Run southeast and fly to the top of the large dragon in Wuthering Waves to grab a casket.

Sonance Casket Location #20

Fast-travel to the middle resonance beacon and run south, then climb another mountain to reach the small dragon and obtain the sonance casket.

Sonance Casket Location #21

Head northwest and climb the tall tilted mountain to get a sonance casket.

Sonance Casket Location #22

Go west-most of the Border Mountain area in Wuthering Waves to reach the small dock and grab the casket.

Sonance Casket Location #23

Teleport to the lower Border Mountains' resonance beacon and fly up to get the sonance casket from under a destroyed bridge.

Capitoline Hill Sonance Casket Location In Wuthering Waves

Sonance Casket Location #24

Go to the western side of Capitoline Hill and take the casket found north of the resonance beacon.

Sonance Casket Location #25

Teleport to the nearby northern beacon and climb the broken grass-covered columns to find the sonance casket.

Sonance Casket Location #26

Turn west and climb the wall guarding the Capitoline Hill and grab the casket from a round building.

Sonance Casket Location #27

Proceed forward along the wall to grab another casket from on top of a second round building.

Sonance Casket Location #28

Glide east to see a sonance casket on top of a mossy arch.

Sonance Casket Location #29

Use flight to go above the wall northwest and get the casket from beneath the broken bridge.

Sonance Casket Location #30

Continue northeast to obtain the sonance casket located at the peak of a mountain.

Sonance Casket Location #31

Turn east and fly down to grab the casket from the top of a ruin.

Sonance Casket Location #32

Now that most of the caskets found on Capitoline Hill's outskirts are collected, go inside the city to collect the rest. Teleport to the beacon found north of Capitoline Hill and fly north to see a casket under a bridge.

Sonance Casket Location #33

Return to the beacon and grab the resonance beacon under the nearby arch.

Sonance Casket Location #34

Head south and fly high to get the next casket.

Sonance Casket Location #35

Teleport to the nearby southern beacon and enter the building west to see a sonance casket.

Sonance Casket Location #36

Go north and grab the following casket located high near the big statue.

Sonance Casket Location #37

Head south of the resonance beacon to find a casket.

Sonance Casket Location #38-39

Proceed southeast and use the flight ability to grab two sonance caskets, one located higher than the other.

Sonance Casket Location #40

Fly above the walls to the southeast and get the casket above the bird statue.​​​​​​​

Sonance Casket Location #41

Glide down even lower to the southwest and get a sonance casket under a rock arch.​​​​​​​

Sonance Casket Location #42

Teleport to the Capitoline Hill's eastern beacon and use the flight ability to reach the top of the huge tower behind it, where you will find a casket.

Sonance Casket Location #43

Fly down north and enter the round building to grab another casket.

Sonance Casket Location #44

Head west and approach an arch to see a sonance casket.

Sonance Casket Location #45

Return to the eastern waypoint and fly east towards the end of the broken bridge to grab a casket.

Sonance Casket Location #46

Continue gliding east and go down to the destroyed building to find a sonance casket inside.​​​​​​​

Vale Of Glory Sonance Casket Location In Wuthering Waves

Sonance Casket Location #47

Head to the Vale of Glory beacon and use flight ability to fly high and grab the sonance casket.

Sonance Casket Location #48

From the edge of the Vale of Glory, fly straight to the isolated island ahead and climb the mountain peak to see a casket.​​​​​​​

Mournfell Canyon Sonance Casket Location In Wuthering Waves

Sonance Casket Location #49

You can either choose a nearby beacon on top of the hill and then jump down near the waterfall to grab the sonance casket, or approach the waterfall and use flight.

Sonance Casket Location #50

Fly west from the waterfall and get the sonance casket found up in the air.

Sonance Casket Location #51

Teleport to the Mournfell Canyon's beacon and fly up north on top of the rocks to get the sonance casket.​​​​​​​

Sonance Casket Location #52

Fast-travel to the resonance nexus and use flight to go southeast and reach the top of a destroyed building.

Sonance Casket Location #53

Next, fly west to the round build on top and grab the sonance casket above it.

Sonance Casket Location #54

Use flight again, this time east, to see a casket on top of some rocks.

Sonance Casket Location #55

Finally, proceed east to some ruins and climb the nearby rock formations to reach the top and grab the final sonance casket.

Collecting all 55 sonance caskets rewards players with The Horn That Never Dies trophy in Wuthering Waves .

What To Do With The Sonance Casket In Wuthering Waves

In the Border Mountains, you will find the Septimont Sonance Casket Collector. Offer all 55 sonance caskets to get valuable rewards in Wuthering Waves like Astrite and so much more.

item.title: Persona 6 Should Take Notes From Clair Obscur: Expedition 33's Status Ailments
item.description:
Like most RPGs, status ailments are tantamount to player strategy in Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 's battle experience. The traditional use of the elements and corresponding effects, like Burn and Stun, are a vehicle for both inflicting and receiving damage, considering the player's ability to break or even stack damage on enemies, and vice versa. Where Clair Obscur takes a step further, however, is in the sheer versatility of these effects, coalescing with its greater combat systems in a way that encourages different approaches.

Through Clair Obscur 's weapons, Pictos, and free aim mechanics, status ailments become not just a detriment, but in some opportunities a boon, setting a strong precedent for other RPGs to follow.

Persona 5 has been cited as one of Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 's chief inspirations, and for good reason. The mainline Persona series, like its SMT origins, has shown just how powerful turn-based combat can be, rewarding its gameplay both through sleek design and the depth that comes with the protagonist's wild card ability. While party members have less degree of freedom, their elemental focuses are testament to team synergy; Persona 5 Royal 's technical damage is evidence of this, showing the merits of ailments and elemental damage being chained together for additional damage. Even still, ailments in the Persona series are generally relegated to base enemies, and though bosses may dish out status conditions of their own, they are, more often than not, insusceptible to the same.

How Clair Obscur: Expedition 33's Status Ailments Underscore Its Combat Nuance

Status Ailments to Encourage Team Synergy

Clair Obscur turns this notion on its head, as ailments are as applicable to boss fights as they are to lesser enemies. Moreover, status conditions take into account the deeper systems of Clair Obscur 's character builds. Like Persona 5 , team synergy is considered; a move like Sciel's Searing Bond, for example, applies additional Foretell if an enemy is burning, while Lune's Thermal Transfer bears a similar advantage, allowing her to regain 4 AP for meeting the same condition. Stunning an enemy is achieved only through specific moves that can break, taking into account the enemy's break gauge as well as elemental tie-ins, like Lune's Earth damage or even base attacks, should players acquire the right Pictos.

Trade-offs That Tie Into Character Builds, Movesets

Already, Clair Obscur shows consideration of how status ailments can be more than what they offer at face value, though this is amplified through its weapons approach. Each member of Clair Obscur 's party can acquire a bevy of weapons that tie into certain skills or battle conditions, and perhaps the most interesting of them are the ones that inflict ailments on the wielder themselves.

Maelle's Stalum, for example, purposefully inflicts Burn onto herself, increasing her damage for each Burn stack in Clair Obscur . The trade-off is, of course, in how she takes damage, but the 10% damage buff per stack can make a considerable difference, and with a Pictos like Double Burn, this process can only quicken per turn. Powering up the weapon to level 20 allows her to heal from the ailment in Defensive Stance, tying further into her unique combat mechanic.

Sciel's Corderon scythe operates on a similar trade-off, but requires more precision and timing in battle to pull off.

Inflicting self-Curse, Sciel only has a number of turns before she automatically dies, with the timer being reset as she enters her Twilight state. This requires players to be mindful of using an attack with a Sun Charge and Moon Charge, which necessitates having enough AP to attack at least twice in the three turns she's given. Another trade-off, Sciel's damage output is increased at the cost of potential death, requiring a careful hand in which skills are utilized.

How Persona 6 Could Take Inspiration

Clair Obscur 's use of the Dizzy ailment is another welcome consideration of status ailments in battle. Dizzy operates in Persona 5 Royal as an accuracy reducer, but in Clair Obscur, it ties into the free aim system, making the aiming reticle sway; often employed by floating enemies who will otherwise dodge non-projectiles, Dizzy becomes less of an automatic debuff and more tied to player skill. Though it is unclear if Persona 6 will incorporate some action elements of its own, the repurposing of Persona 5 's guns into a free aim system could hold similar merits.

The same rings true for its weapons, especially with how demon transmutation has worked in past Persona and SMT games. Perhaps a weapon transmuted from a demon of the Faith Arcana could provide increased damage if the protagonist wields another Faith Persona in battle, or maybe imbue base attacks with a Light Affinity. Alternatively, a weapon for a Zio-based party member could increase their damage output at the random chance to self-inflict Stun, resulting in a similar trade-off system.

item.title: Tainted Grail: The Fall of Avalon Gets Helpful New Update
item.description:
Developer Questline has recently released a new update for the popular RPG Tainted Grail: The Fall of Avalon . With strong Skyrim vibes and an expansive open world to explore, Tainted Grail: The Fall of Avalon has been an excellent surprise for players, and its devs seem to be focused on polishing the experience even more.

Created as an indirect sequel to the story-driven roguelike RPG Tainted Grail: Conquest , Tainted Grail: The Fall of Avalon finally received its 1.0 release back in May after being in early access for over a year. The game is set in a dark world inspired by the Arthurian legends, and offers a lengthy open-world experience with three main regions, a branching storyline, and hundreds of quests. However, as expected for such a large game made by a small team, Tainted Grail: Fall of Avalon also launched with quite a few bugs.

Now, developer Questline and publisher Awaken Realms have released Patch 1.04 for Tainted Grail: The Fall of Avalon . The new update comes with many fixes, improving a few technical aspects of the game, as well as fixing glitches in multiple quests. However, the patch also came with some interesting additions, such as 29 new fish, as well as more fishing spots being included in the game's world. Another major change that may please gamers is that the developers added Tier 4 and 5 weapons to the possible loot from higher-tier Unidentified Items.

The new patch comes on the heels of a major update for Tainted Grail: The Fall of Avalon , released earlier this month. The previous update was focused on solving issues, and it corrected a major save file bug that could make players lose their progress. It also offered several fixes, including patching some quests that were broken.

It’s nice to see Questline making major updates to its open-world RPG so swiftly, especially considering how well-regarded Tainted Grail: The Fall of Avalon has been. At the time of this report, Tainted Grail: The Fall of Avalon has 'Very Positive' reviews on Steam, with 87% of over 13,000 gamers enjoying the title.

Since its 1.0 release, Tainted Grail: The Fall of Avalon has been greatly popular, resonating with fans of both open-world games and dark fantasy RPGs. As reported last month, The Fall of Avalon was very popular on Twitch, averaging around 13,000 viewers after its release, which put it above massively popular games like the recent Oblivion Remastered on the platform at the time.

Tainted Grail: The Fall of Avalon Update v1.04 Patch Notes (June 16, 2025)

Gameplay

  • Allowed using stashed items at the Blacksmith Table
  • Added Tier 4 and 5 weapons to the possible loot from higher-tier Unidentified Items
  • Dual Wielding Spells no longer unlock Mana Regen while channeling & casting simultaneously
  • Reworked Fishing balance. If you find it difficult to catch some fish, we recommend looking for better fishing rods
  • Added 29 new fishes (and updated corresponding achievements)
  • Updated Fishing spots across all of Avalon. Remember that some fish only appear at certain times or in certain bodies of water
  • Fixed the following talents: Fury Without Fatigue, Shieldbearer, Mighty Blows
  • Lunge attacks will no longer trigger while walking with a high movement speed multiplier
  • 2 Wyrdspirits joined the combat encounter in Ghost Realm
  • Rebalanced the cook and alchemist shops in the castle in HoS
  • Fixed the Severing Ray damage calculation
  • Replaced Thunder Lash spell with Thunderstrike in HoS Stronghold
  • Added Gytha’s shop in Volker village and fixed her dialogue

Quests

  • Anselm, Maggot, and Yvain should return to their interiors (if they have disappeared for you)
  • Fixed blocker in Vrell dialogue when finishing the Temptation quest while having already finished the next objective
  • A Carnation to Remember won’t fail if it’s already completed
  • Fixed incorrect descriptions of some quest items
  • The incorrectly failed objective in quest “The Price of Healing” is now fixed
  • Fixed Pup being freed by save & load
  • Orlaith should take your package even if you request a reward
  • The dialogue option about reward from “This is the Part Where You Run Away” should be visible, but blocked, even without the proof
  • \[Quest: Sweet Dreams] Fixed the loading of autosave in the Sympathy and Trickster realm, breaking dialogue trigger
  • A cave between Cuanacht’s Gardens and the Plains will now correctly become accessible as you progress the Children of Morrigan questline. Before that, it will be blocked by a rock
  • The Price of Healing quest and Neante and Yvain funding interactions improved
  • Yngvi’s dialogue shouldn’t block the hero
  • Wayward Son quest forces the hero to look at the outcome (so the logic won’t break)
  • The Construct dialogue can now be triggered when a weapon is equipped

Technical

  • [Critical] Returning to Cuanacht and a couple of dungeons after a long time shouldn’t break scene loading
  • [Steam] Fixed a possible corruption of Steam cloud files if the game crashed/PC crashed during cloud update
  • No more free money! Selling items during sorting won’t make you rich anymore. This also fixes the item duplication glitch. If you really want infinite of certain items, you can always look at mods, such as unlocking the debug console
  • Talent effects should update correctly after changing player perspective (some of them didn’t)
  • NPC audio should now follow its body when in ragdoll instead of playing in place of death, etc.
  • Fixed an issue with being stuck in the crouched state after fast travelling from a fireplace
  • Fixed incorrect refresh of the selected list item after sorting when using a gamepad.npc
  • Fixed edge case bugs in the rain system
  • Fixed small memory leaks generated by the rain system
  • Fixed performance issue when using two-handed weapons with AOE Crushing Blow talent.
  • Fixed some minor bugs that appeared when using the Thunderous Greatbow
  • Fixed missing starting furniture after purchasing only the Cuanacht home
  • Sveinn Village’s overall stability increased

Graphics

  • Improved color correction in the Spawn Tibby VFX
  • Optimized texture size in the Rock VFX for better performance
  • Improved fire visuals and distortion effects in prologue wyrdness
  • Removed transition flickering during fast travel
  • Fixed Ulfr Guards displaying incorrect clan tattoos
  • Vragi’s Mother’s placeholder model was replaced with a monster form
  • Your hand should now be visible when placing the bonfire
  • Wyrddeers from Stagfather‘s Trial are now spawning and despawning with a proper dissolve effect
  • Fixed female armor piece not displaying for Battlemage Tunic
  • Added new icons for several summoning spells
  • Changed the appearance of Deathbound Guardians and Blood Abomination summons
  • Dressed up a dead body on the Plains of Cuanacht
  • Improved VFX for Arthur’s initial appearance in the resurrection room
  • Added Theud tattoos to Frail

Audio

  • Fixed missing and broken VOs for some NPCs (Egill, Self, Flaithri, Stigr, Eyvor, Elira, Heledd, Yngvi, King Arthur, Flyrna, Kjell, Barlaam, Theud Mother, Hrafn, Heiko, Galahad, Sir Vast, Darvhanr, Turtar)
  • Added audio to the EldritchReaver Generic
  • Changed the explosions’ audio volume levels
  • Fixed the bear audio
  • Added audio to FrostbittenWarrior Female and T5_Skeleton1H
  • Changed Zombie attack volume level
  • Removed the duplicated line of Maggot during one of the story interactions

Localizations

  • Fixed incorrect display of characters in fonts that support Cyrillic script

Misc

  • Fixed Neante holding a comically large piece of paper in her house
  • Added more NPC interactions to the Ulfr Barracks
  • Fixed the interactability of fireplaces in some dungeons
  • The buried chest in Mountain Ice Cave is now diggable
  • Fixed Smuggler’s Dagger description to properly display the Critical Damage increase when upgrading the item
  • Changed loot in Shrine Cellars
  • Repaired the first mist gate in King’s Threat dungeon (now it should block you until after the fight)
  • Broth no longer gives bread instead of broth
  • Added a treasure chest in the Ruined Towers in Cuanacht
  • Crafting/Blacksmithing: pressing the selection button again on an already selected recipe or item now jumps to the ingredients/gems (gamepad)
  • Removed unnecessary interactions with decorative flowerpots
